Looking away is what people have been doing all over the country for decades, including in the case of Leo and Ella Stein.  and their Circle S Ranch.  In the early 1950s, Leo Stein, a Jewish student of Freudian psychology, and his wife Ella Stein, founded a boys' ranch in the Arizona desert outside of Phoenix.  Stein had previously been fired from the local school board and even investigated by the FBI for attempting to teach atheism, communism, and sex ed with a weird focus on what he perceived every boy's desire was, having sex with their mother.  But for some reason, and somehow, this man with no psychiatric training whatsoever was the man that, for some reason, the system in both Arizona and Southern California decided to send their troubled teens to.  They sent boys from ages 12 to 18 to his secluded compound in the middle of the desert.  His compound called Circle S Ranch for nearly 25 years.  And for nearly 25 years, Leo and his wife Ella abused and molested young boys repeatedly.  And despite several complaints with matching stories from boys who didn't know each other that spanned decades, who had been at the ranch decades apart, it was allowed to continue because nobody wanted to believe it was happening.  Even after a boy, Larry Middleton, who was staying at the ranch, was found dead in the desert in 1958.  And nobody was annoyed by the Steins' uncooperative nature.  And for some reason, nobody investigated further.  You see, the boy had simply wandered off into the desert.  He had simply wandered off in the desert and died of heat stroke. So what happened to Leo and Ella Stein?  Well, pretty much nothing.  The Steins were ordered to have no contact with children under 18, but there was no jail time.  Leo ended up dying of prostate cancer in 1994, and his wife died almost 20 years later, quietly in the same town where she and her husband had been abusing children for decades.  In fact, to this day, despite the Steins admitting to much of the sexual abuse, of course disguised as unorthodox therapy methods, while researching this case, I came across several posts on the internet from acquaintances of the Steins still in denial of what is now a matter of public record because they didn't want to believe that they had lived next door to monsters and done nothing.  And make no mistake, they don't want to refuse to believe this because what it would mean for the children.  They refuse to believe it because what it would mean for them.

The Circle S is closed now, but that does not lessen the emotional harm that Donald and others say was done to them.  For all we know, there are worse places than Circle S operating today.  It is important to remember that the truth about Circle S came out almost by accident, and that right up to the last minute, government agencies in several states were using public money to subject youngsters to what Leo Stein called therapy.
